comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This is H.M.S. Curacoa, a ship of the Royal Navy. This one was a third class cruiser, formerly a screw corvette. Here is a circa 1890 photograph at the Australian War Memorial: cas.awm.gov.au/photograph/302169 and an 1890 photograph from the State Library of South Australia here: images.slsa.sa.gov.au/mpcimg/10750/B10531.htm The curator's notes at the Powerhouse Museum's persistent URL say this may possibly be Mort's dock. It may also be Fitzroy Dock at Cockatoo Island. See the identical rock formations at the left hand side of this photograph: naa12.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp?M=0&am...

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I've just noticed that there is a second ship in the dry dock, one that appears to have two masts and two funnels.

comment._content: Here's a good comparison pic of Fitzroy Dock. Compare the rock formation on the left side of the dock here: www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/1472304960/in/set-72157...

comment.author: 97381978@N00
comment._content: HMS Curacoa was sold out of RN service in 1904 while the Victorian paint job pre-dates 1902/1903. Please add to: Naval History

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Nautical pictures of interest., and we'd love to have this added to the group! Nice and interesting shot.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Definitely Sutherland Dock (completed 1890) on Cockatoo Island from the rectangular sticky-out bits at each side (they show up in the Google satellite photo), and from the overhanging building mid-left. See comments here - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5889052507/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The only relevant references I can find via Trove for "Curacoa Sutherland" are two - 1} 'Australian Town and Country Journal' - 26/11/1892 p.38, col.1 (near the top) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/5237097 . "HMS Rapid and HMS Curacoa have gone to the Sutherland Dock." HMS 'Rapid' (1883) had three masts and one funnel, so NOT the ship in front (thanks BobMeade) - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:HMS_Rapid_(1883)_AWM_302249.jpeg 2) SMH 13/2/1893 p.7 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13897368 - "H.M.S. Curacoa and Walleroo, which have been in the Sutherland Dock for the past eight weeks, came out of dock on Saturday and anchored in Farm Cove. Both boats have been thoroughly overhauled, and the difficulty experienced owing to a galvanic or chemical action between the copper and steel linings on the bottom of the Curacoa has been remedied." HMS 'Wallaroo' (1890) had two masts and funnels - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Wallaroo_(1890) - could that be the ship in front ? (see BobMeade's note). And the date for this photo as early 1893 ? Several other Phillips Collection images are about this time.
